entry.content:
I don’t usually hold on to episodes for too long, but I waited to post this until my guest had revamped her site. Marie Teather is my guest today, and she’s the face behind Worldette, a website where women can connect with each other wherever they are in the world. The site helps to inspire travel and breakdown boundaries that women might have in terms of getting out and seeing the world. Marie’s story of how she became an international expat is a good one, so don’t miss it!

Here are some more highlights from the episode slice:

  • How she started her international career in Japan and ended up loving it
  • How her English teaching job in Japan led her to follow her passion for journalism
  • The culture shock that she faced when she came back to London after living in Japan
  • What she’s doing in Hong Kong
  • Why there are often really good job opportunities for expats in other countries
  • How making connections is vital if you want to do something else besides teaching English
  • The book that changed Marie’s life (buy it here)

Make sure to head over to Worldette and connect with Marie!

Marie Teather

entry.content:
One word to describe today’s episode slice: Fascinating. If you’re interesting in living and/or teaching in Jordan as an expat, you are going to love this interview. American Morgan Byrne-Diakun is my guest. He originally came over to Jordan to work as an administrator for a study abroad program (CET). He still works for CET, but he also teaches English because there were so many great opportunities that he couldn’t pass up! We discuss life as a teacher and as an expat in Jordan.

Here are some more topics we discuss:

  • Morgan’s background and how he made it over to Jordan
  • Benefits, pay scale for teachers, accommodation, and visa info
  • Expat communities in Jordan
  • Requirements to teach English in Jordan (hint: be a native English speaker)
  • How he found his teaching jobs
  • Challenges that expat women may face in Jordan and overall safety
  • His own biggest challenges of living in Jordan
  • Advice for people looking to teach or live in Jordan
  • Discrimination that Jews may face in Jordan

Morgan Byrne-Diakun

Any questions or comments? Leave them below in the comments section!

entry.content:
Travel bloggers and former English teachers in Korea Audrey Bergner (That Backpacker) and Samuel Jeffery (Nomadic Samuel) are on the show today. Combined, this pair has spent over four years teaching English in Korea. And, they have a super awesome YouTube channel (Backpacking Travel TV) PLUS another blog called Backpacking Travel Blog. Let’s just say they’re no strangers to online media.

We are deep diving today into Sam and Audrey’s lives as English teachers in Korea. Originally, I had been thinking about keeping this video for a guide I thought about making about teaching English in Korea, but I nixed the idea and am now going to share with you all! We cover a lot of bases, so if you are interested in teaching English in Korea, pay attention. This video is for you.

Here’s just some of what we cover. 

  • How they found their teaching jobs (helpful sites and recruiters they used)
  • Differences between teaching jobs in Korea (private vs public vs older kids vs younger kids)
  • The goods – benefits (salary, accommodation, vacation time, etc.)
  • TEFL certification programs they used
  • Favorite and least favorite parts of teaching English in Korea
  • Their social life, mingling with other expats, and learning basic Korean
  • Funny/quirky stories about living in Korea (spam and freckles)
  • Anything they know now that they wish they knew before they came to Korea to teach
  • Lots of advice about teaching English in Korea

… and so much more!

Connect with Sam and Audrey

Sam and Audrey were super helpful, down to Earth, and I really appreciated them sitting down with me to chat. They even went to a quiet cafe with good Internet to ensure a good connection. Thanks you two! Make sure to head over to their websites and connect with them via social media.

Samuel Jeffery and Audrey Bergner

entry.content:
Allison Lounes, founder of Paris Unraveled: The Student’s Guide to Living and Studying in France, is on the show today! And, the 50th episode wouldn’t be complete without some sort of freebie, right? Well, Allison is giving away her e-book on Amazon titled How to Save $40,000 Studying Abroad in France. But, the giveaway is only lasting about a day, so head on over to Amazon ASAP!

Now, for a little bit more on Paris Unraveled and the episode slice. Paris Unraveled makes your study abroad experience in France stress-free AND helps enroll you in a French Master’s program. Allison and her team help students find housing, aid in the visa process, edit their papers for grammatical mistakes, get students involved in the community, and so on. Basically, they take care of all the challenges you might face when living and studying in France. Pretty sweet. Allison is on to share her story of how she built her life in France and saved a ton of money studying there locally.

Here are some more highlights from the interview!

  • How getting a Master’s through a public university in France saved her A LOT of money (I’m talking $30k)
  • The challenges she faced on her own when she was over there (housing, visa, social life, working, etc.)
  • Her teaching experience with TAPIF: Teaching English Assistant Program in France
  • The awesome program she created to assist students who come to France

… and so much more!

Make sure to head on over to Paris Unraveled to connect with Allison.

entry.summary:

The post 10 Live & Work Abroad Rockstars Whose Stories Will Make You Say “Wow” appeared first on Atlas Sliced.
entry.content:
Today’s slice (post) is a little different. There’s no video. Instead, I’m giving a shout-out to 10 people who I think deserve a mention and made me say “wow” when I first learned about them. They are all doing or have done very unique things abroad, but the bond that ties them together is that they are all living creatively and passionately on their own terms.

Let’s get started!

1 & 2) Alex Navarrete and Crystal Bodell – Born to Backpack

Hiking and sporting the BTB t-shirts!

Wow Factor: Raise the roof wow

Why? This under 30 dynamic duo saved up money from their jobs and started a new eco-friendly apparel line that redefines what it means to be a global citizen. After months of hard work and planning, they decided to quit their day jobs and take their biz on the road with them, as they manage everything remotely and travel the world. Can’t wait to air their episode slice (stay tuned for a contest in the near future). I feel honored and privileged to know them personally and have a tremendous amount of respect for these global entrepreneurs. Alex and Crystal are a super friendly couple, so make sure to say hello to them on Facebook and Twitter.

3) Hilary Corna – Founder of LiveAndWorkAbroad.org and author of One White Face

Hilary Corna

Wow Factor: Jump out of my seat wow

Why? Former guest Hilary Corna went into the international corporate world after graduating from university. The crazy part is how she got her job with Toyota Motor Asia Pacific in Singapore, after buying a one-way ticket with no plans. It all started in a swimming pool. Seriously. She was the “one white face” in her Singapore office, and her story of working in Asia’s corporate culture is so unique that I couldn’t put her book down when I was reading it. Give Hilary some love on Facebook and Twitter.

4) Turner Barr – Around the World in 80 Jobs

Turner Barr doing an odd job

Wow Factor: Jaw dropping wow

Why? Atlas Sliced alum Turner Barr might be a little bit crazy. And that’s why I like him. He’s just so darn unconventional that I always want to know what he’s up to next. For those who don’t know him, he goes all over the world picking up odd jobs (ex. harvesting tequila in Mexico, making pizza in Rome, street salesman in Thailand) to support his lifestyle. Give him a shout out on Twitter and follow him on Facebook. His Facebook updates are hilarious.

5) Sherry Ott – Creator of Ottsworld and Co-founder of Meet Plan Go!

Sherry Ott (Photo taken from Ottsworld.com)

Wow Factor: Bust out the jello shots wow

Why? Sherry Ott quit her New York corporate IT job in 2006 to travel. She’s not just a typical traveler who writes and takes photos about her experiences. She’s an entrepreneur. Sherry turned her corporate runaway story into a way to help others escape the cubicle by creating Meet Plan Go!, which offers career break planning and advice through online courses and events across North America. She is also a “new nomad.” Make sure to connect with her on Facebook and Twitter. Did I mention she likes jello shots?

6) Jodi Ettenberg – Creator of Legal Nomads and author of The Food Traveler’s Handbook

Jodi Ettenberg (Photo taken from LegalNomads.com)

Wow Factor: Hot damn! wow

Why? As the name of her site suggests, Jodi Ettenberg used to be a lawyer. But those days are long gone. She had been set on traveling the world most of her life, but she needed to save up money before she could do it. What’s so cool about her is that she keeps her site ad-free and supports herself through partnerships that she has created with others. Oh, and I almost forgot to mention that she’s a food enthusiast and wrote a book (see title above) about finding “cheap, safe and delicious food anywhere in the world.” I’m sure she’d appreciate connecting on Facebook and Twitter.

7) Shannon O’Donnell – Creator of A Little Adrift, Grassroots Volunteering and author of The Volunteer Traveler’s Handbook

Shannon O’Donnell (Photo taken from ALittleAdrift.com)

Wow Factor: Epiphany-inducing wow

Why? Another Atlas Sliced alum, Shannon O’Donnell has taken her skills on the road with her over the years, as she works basically anywhere in the world doing freelance writing, SEO consulting, and online marketing. She has also volunteered extensively and wrote a book (see above title). Another very unique quirk about her is that she took her young niece, who was homeschooled at the time, along with her for an extended period of her travels. What an awesome aunt! Track her down on Facebook and Twitter to say hello.

8) Marcello Arrambide – Creator of Wandering Trader and The Day Trading Academy

Marcello Arrambide (Photo taken from WanderingTrader.com)

Wow Factor: Off the charts impressive wow

Why? I’ll be honest. To me, day trading looks like a cluster of graphs, numbers, and confusion. But Marcello Arrambide seems to have cracked the code. He makes a living day trading and training people how to day trade. Major props to him because this is something I don’t think I could do. All the while, he travels to off the beaten path countries like South Sudan and Suriname. He’s living life on the wild side! Give Marcello a holler on Facebook and Twitter.

9 & 10) Christine and Drew Gilbert – Creators of The Wireless Generation (documentary) and Almost Fearless (Christine)

Drew and Christine Gilbert. Photo taken from their Kickstarter campaign.

Wow Factor: Fist pump wow

Why? This couple left the U.S. to pursue traveling the world in 2008. Oh, and they had a baby while on the road (probably two babies by the time you read this). No big deal. I’m super stoked for the release of their documentary, which is about a “new generation of people taking their careers online in order to travel the world.” Seriously A-MAZ-ING. Connect with Christine on Facebook and Twitter.

Bonus (two people you probably already know about but need to be mentioned)

Chris Guillebeau: Chris elicits an “I don’t even know what to say” wow. He is an entrepreneur, an author, a speaker, and a travel hacker who has been to almost EVERY COUNTRY in the world (soon to be all). I could write a ton about him, but if you don’t know him, get your head out from under a rock and head over to his site.

Where the Hell is Matt? Makes me wanna do a happy dance wow. Long story short (read the full story on his site), Matt started doing a silly dance all over the world, and he filmed it. It caught on big time. Now he makes a living through speaking engagements, endorsements, and appearances.

Know other people who could value from learning about these rockstars? Awesome! Share away on Facebook, Twitter, G+, or anywhere else your heart desires.

Click here to share easily on Twitter!

I’m sure I have left out some great people. Know anyone else doing similar things and beating to the tune of his/her own drum? Let me know in the comments!

The post EPISODE SLICE #48: One White Face – Working Abroad in the Corporate World appeared first on Atlas Sliced.
entry.content:
This episode slice has been a long time coming. Hilary Corna and I had been trying to  nail down an interview for the LONGEST time. We finally did it, and here it is. Hilary is the author of the memoir One White Face, founder of LiveAndWorkAbroad.org, and a public speaker (TEDx Talk is here). She has a really unique story because she went into the international corporate world after graduating from university.

Here’s the super cliffs notes version. She bought a one-way ticket to Singapore and gave herself two months to find a job. She “found” a great position (You will want to know how. It’s amazing.) with Toyota Motor Asia Pacific, and as the title of her book implies, she was the “one white face” working there. I highly recommend that you read her book.

Here are some highlights from the interview

  • How she wouldn’t have gotten the position had she been working in the U.S.
  • Major differences between Asian work culture and Western work culture and why people “fail” at jobs overseas
  • Advice on landing a job abroad
  • Why keeping a notebook or journal with you when you are abroad is a great idea
  • How building connections plays a big role

… and SO MUCH MORE!

Hilary is the epitome of a global citizen. Make sure to check out One White Face and Live & Work Abroad.

Hilary Corna
